newsitem.title: CANADA: BASEBALL-BLUE JAYS MANAGER ACCUSES SOME MEDIA MEMBERS OF RACISM.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-BLUE JAYS MANAGER ACCUSES SOME MEDIA MEMBERS OF RACISM.

text.p: The Toronto Blue Jays baseball team was embroiled in a racism controversy on Thursday, two days after Major League Baseball honoured Jackie Robinson's breaking of the colour line 50 years ago.
Blue Jays manager Cito Gaston, the first black manager to win the World Series, has accused some critics in the local media of racism, Toronto newspapers reported.
"There's a couple (of sports writers) who continue to take shots at me for no reason at all. I just wonder if they would take the same shot at me if I was white," Gaston said in the Toronto Sun.
Gaston's comments were made during an interview with the Sun earlier this week as baseball celebrated Robinson's 1947 breathrough with the old Brooklyn Dodgers.
Gaston has led the Blue Jays for eight years and managed them to back-to-back World Series titles in 1992 and 1993.
But his low-key management style has been criticised by some members of the local media.
Gaston suggested during a pre-game radio show on Tuesday that criticism of his decisions by local broadcaster Bob McCowan and others may be linked to the colour of his skin.
"What else can they be," Gaston said during show prior to the Blue Jays' game against the Kansas City Royals.
"(Is it) because of your colour or because they just don't like you? How the heck can they not like you when they don't know you," Gaston said.
McCowan, a broadcaster with The Fan, an all-sports radio station in Toronto, asked the Blue Jays for a meeting with Gaston on Thursday.

"I have said on the air many times that it was possible, maybe probable, that my opinion of him as a manager is clouded by my personal dislike for him. I've willingly acknowledged that I may be biased. But I'm not racist," McCowan told Toronto's Globe and Mail on Thursday.
